Grails Overview

Lecture 05

A Web Application "Vertical Slice"

  • javascript - Dynamic behavior in the browser
  • servlets - HTML page generation
  • controllers - Application Form Controllers + Tests
  • command - Display objects + Tests
  • validation - Validation and constraints + Tests
  • services - Service Layer + Tests
  • queries - Data access + Tests
  • domain - Domain Model + Tests
  • DDL - Database Schema

Grails Application Stack

Plugins

Grails is built on Plugins!

  • https://grails.org/plugins
  • There are 500+ plugins available
  • They are light-weight and easy to write
  • They are easy to install
  • Installation is scoped by app, not system

They often include additional scripts to provide additional functionality:

  • Scaffolding template support for login pages
  • Spring Security default tables for users and roles

Why Grails?

  • Proven productivity - 30-45% in real-world enterprise projects
  • Solve many problems with Java projects
    • Common Build System
    • Common Deployment
    • Common Technology Stack
    • Common Configuration
  • Easier to Build and Maintain
    • Write less code! (Convention / Configuration)
    • Common project structure across all Grails projects

Grails Project Conventions

Complete application structure is scaffolded with predefined directories for:

  • Controllers
  • Domain classes
  • views
  • Custom Java or Groovy classes
  • i18n Messages
  • templates
  • Automated Build / Test Scripts
  • development / test / production / Custom Environments

GGTS Demo

Let's do this!

Environment Setup

Make you machine work!

Creating a working directory

  • Open the global_server/scratch drive
  • Open the IntroToGrails folder
  • Copy/Paste the grails-training-materials.zip to your pc's desktop.
  • Unzip the package onto your desktop
  • Just use your desktop for now. We'll move these files in a moment
  • Don't put it on your Y drive and unzip. The network makes this very slow.

Grails Config

  • In your Y: drive
  • Open the folder '.grails'
  • Copy/Paste grails configs into this directory
    • ProxySettings.groovy
    • settings.groovy
  • These files are in the class materials

Class Materials

  • Copy these files to a place you want
    • labs.pdf
    • timeclock.png
    • Slide Deck

You will be using these during the class, so put them where you can find them easily

Setup Workspace

  • Copy the entire intro-to-grails-solved.zip into your C:/GGTSWorkspaces folder.
  • Unzip the package in the same folder.

Setup GGTS

  • Open GGTS - Wait for the 'Workspace' prompt
    • If already open, File -> Switch Workspace
  • Explore to C:/GGTSWorkspaces/intro-to-grails-solved (Or similar)
  • Click OK to use this workspace

Import the projects

  • You should see 2 projects in the project explorer
    • groovyLab1_solved
    • timesheet_solved
  • If the projects are not there, we will need to import them.
    • In GGTS, select File -> Import
    • Select General -> Existing Files into workspace
    • For the root directory, browse to the workspace
    • Make sure both projects are checked

Run the finished product

  • Open the timesheet_solved project
  • Right-click on the project
  • select Run As -> Grails Command (run-app)
  • Wait for the console to display a link to
  • http://localhost:8080/timesheet2
  • Click the link
  • login with username: 'john', password: 'password'
  • Explore!!!

Did that work?

Due to some firewall settings at MoO, we need to setup a proxy that allows grails to download plugins and sources from their repositories.

  • Within the Grails prompt:
    • add-proxy mutual --host=proxy_server --port=8020
    • set-proxy mutual

Creating a Grails Application

If you are lucky enough to be starting a Grails application from scratch, getting everything setup is easy to do.

  • File -> New -> Grails Project
    • app name becomes default package
    • follows common convention for projects
      • i.e. projects with names like com.opi.timesheet
    • creates a default project structure by convention
  • App is runnable
  • default web server is included
  • built in scripts
  • clean, compile
  • automated unit and integration tests
  • package app into a deployable war file

Notes for lab

On steps to install plugins, use these versions:

  • Spring-Security-Core 1.2.7.3 version
  • Joda-Time 1.4 version
